titleStmt.title: M47 [Anon: For why a gods name...]. Holograph fragments, undated. Some pages paginated 1-3. 11p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M47 [Anon: For why a gods name...]. Holograph fragments, undated. Some pages paginated 1-3. 11p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: For why a gods name

– thus he proves that he was word conscious, an artist,
aware of the possibilities, of the limitations of his medium.
Its He The aware that words, not paint, not music; words themselves.
He To be thus aware of language, the writer must
have a past behind him, just as the historian must, in
order to see the present moment, must set it against the past in counter [illeg.]
behind him. There must be a golden age; the
must be corrupt, degenerate, fallen. But
The golden age of English was to the age of
– "Dan Chaucer, well of English undefiled"
The language He There is The he
Chaucer again – he prays: that the infusion
sweete
of thine owne spirit which doth in me survive
He But there It is the language he loves
Unlike In his At his moment

It was He looked back to Chaucer –
differing from the What Spenser saw this was
then across the dumb age of church buildings, of
was the long Chaucer It was
The language of Chaucer was what he his
It was by Chaucer by through Chaucer that saw himself
his work [illeg.] the measure of his own speech.
Where the modern writer wrote a long time of
has close at hand attacks the generation which
has just gone, using them as the his taking off in the opposite direction
lane of departure, C Spenser's had no
revolt was against no particular writer, but
against the language itself, its decay, since
Chaucer, its corruption. Perhaps This once
Partly perhaps, Whe Perhaps as an antidote

When the , the wife of who the poet
who was executed comes to the surface writes, she writes:
Only in some extremity of passion or of need do they come to
take up the pen. She The sound of the Bible is in
their ears. As if It is a garment only to be put on when the
being is in an attitude a certain attitude.
And the garment may of course conceal a
who is merry, who is, normally, occupied with
happy amused, or charming, or – we cannot tell
what real woman lives in the other side of that
wall of words.

Using the prose of the Bible then, the
Elizabethans are shut off from us. They can say
nothing subtle, nothing little. Bright contrasted
colours meet on their faces: carnation & snow, ebony &
gold. Stitched into their doublets, the young men look
Young men's bodies look are stiffly sewn into padded
doublets, school boys faces are raised above
starched collars & young women serve only to
display heavy [guiled?] robes [strewn?] about with
huge pearls.

p.s:
The separation of the writer from the audience–
was the creation of a an art of writing, profession art
seems to have been slow
When the the writer
The writer The speaking voice When the
the speaking voice is concealed with the writing voice
If familiar letters are written in biblical English,
the writer cannot be then the writer

div.p:
from the air foundations of old houses are still marked, we should see the house
in connected with the village. We should see here a
ring in the a ring, an oasis, in the midst of
fields & forests: the road a mere track: & the
oasis thus like a fortress built against the
uncivilised country; if out, against the sige siege – the
everlasting sieve. of If the enemy comes there are is
armour in the church. If [flood?] & hunger. then there is
grain in the great barn. And for the spirit there it is
too and to feed the mind But for the hunger of the
mind, the curiosity, the desire to escape from
there were books [illeg.] That connection is
between house & church, master & labourer,
is obvious detailed in the letters, making
indeed the staple of that correspondence. But
the less visible connections is to there is was also the
other connection, which, just as the of
the bodily connection was looked ended by
the has become almost invisible now; the
that bond between the great house & the small
has faded till it is like one of those perhaps
rather greener lanes her still to be found in England
along which antiquarians say the went to

so the scholars tell us that how
long before Chaucer, how long before the to
Christians came, the sun was fire was a god was worshipped
or the sea was a god, & how their
ancient worship was went was beneath the
other; & how the harvest was & they

The man then who stood on the threshold of the great
Elizabethan room was separate from the chronicler
separate from , the singer, & separate from
the chronicler. He was separate from his
audience. He had emerged; But Directly
the creative instinct, the desire to had singled out
chosen words for its medium. And The pre press which
had given him those words a separate existence;
the reader had been had called into ex
created a reader: & the reader, the individual
an un public, a reading public, to And with the
existence of a public began to exert its
presentce. But it was a small public, an aristocratic public. And then, when we
find Spenser, standing at the door, we
can And so, with Spenser perhaps
we come for the first time into the
presence of to the book which is influenced
not anonymous, not spontaneous, not
is influenced; not in which we can still
detect other the beginning of all it
all those tugs, plays additions, influences,
of apart from the original and pure
interior. playing on the original instinct &
giving it that alloy [illeg.] when which
as time goes on, become so innumerable
that so distracting: the presence effect of the
audience – could we the curiousness
who will read this; what will be to
their liking, what will offend them
What book will find favour with Lady
Ann? What will please
what will flatter the

the group of nobles, after hunting? what will prove that
Edmund Spenser, for example, deserves a post, a pension?
Thes These are the outer influences that stamp
themselves upon the pure desire. Thus This is the
atmosphere which draws out, finds, at some times
is favourable, at others checks & [illeg.]
But Further, there are Further there are the other
influences; the del pressure of wealth, rank. & leisure
education, & class, wealth & poverty always
at their work, tugging, obscuring distorting.
Some are visible only to the writer himself;
others only to the reader. More & more
complex do they become, as the book with the
author's name on it goes out to a
larger public, to a more complex public, to a
public that has emerged sufficiently from
the silence of the middle ages to be
educated, partly educated, to desire
humour, story, amusement, instruction,
or [illeg.] something to make them forget what
the private life which is so drab.
When Spenser wrote When the book is thus
covered over, An the song, the thing that the
writer set out to say, begomes increasingly
disguised. It is only to be discovered in a
flash of recognition; some say they feel it
when their beards bristle; others that a
thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh.
To disengage the sur song from the
influence of the audience becomes a
task for the critic –– an official who
scarcely exists when Spenser emerged from

depths of silence, writing that was long vast poem
the

The artist however had chosen his medium. The
great English art was not to be l music, or painting:
it was to be the art of words. And if we call
we call Spenser the first artist, it is because we can
are aware of his of his he was awareness of his medium
He was conscious not only of his public, not only
of his own need, a poor man, of patronage &
support, but of the limitations of the fact that
the language was truly an [incitement?]
It "Let us be Kings of our language...
Let In order to be an artist, must one
The writer, like the chronicler, in order to see his
medium cautiously, must be aware of the past
There There must be a golden age behind him; &
y the present must be fallen, degenerate.
But which we the modern writer, who has a
long tradition behind him, who naturally
attacks the old generation which has just
past, thus giving himself a person to
revolt against, the writer in Spenser's time,
had no definite past. This is a more general
reaction. This rather a sense of the
[delicacy? debauchery?] the decay the language of its
that he has to correct, rather than
his actual predecessors.

Thus Spenser, on the threshold of his
work as a poet, did not demolish his
predecessors; he complained of the
debasement of English speech: & the
He used the old Chaucerian language
recovered the old words, the
words. He Curious perhaps of his own

The writer then, came to birth with difficulty in England:
for so long as familiar letters are written in biblical
prose, he must remain be only confined there are
limits to his –– something that remains unfitting
a to his freedom; a barrier between the sayable &
the unsayable. He is writing, for the printing press has
given him a name; but as yet suppressed in the
submerged; it oppressed, by what the
contorted at many by wh in the inadequacy in of his
instrument; its which, when it if it seems must
take evade dumb, unable, that is,
it cannot but he still submerged; partly by
unspecialised, undifferentiated. There is a passage in
The eye was For one He was, seeing; The artist
is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or wholly
painter. It seems possible that the great English art
may not be the art of words. His
eye was is stimulated in that empty world, by the
colours of the of the clothing. His ear was
stimulated by the sound of music words. "Pritchard" said
read aloud They The Faery Queen..."
England was given substance & sharpness of the
speaking voice. And the music gave lilt &
rhythm, melody to the spoken word.
"Hardly one lighter or boat in three that had the
goods of a home in it " but there was a
pair of virginals in it" observed, in 1666,
when the people of London were loading their
goods onto boats in the great fire. His
world then was full of undifferentiated words:

old words & new words; French & Latin. No grammar
held them tightly together. They were elastic, they
could be danced to & sung to. But they could
not follow the sound of the speaking voice.

then in the seems like a
half articulate monster, rising from the depths of

the deep sea in which the writer had been
submerged. The Faery Queen: is we cannot read it: the Faerie Queene (Fr Q.)
we cannot leave it unread. This is a poem without a plot;
the metre, casting its regular fling, but somehow
comes to ground too [wholy?]. Unlike who
goes ahead, simply, directly, It The Knights, the
ladies, become loo are see disembodied:
what & the But we cannot leave it unread:
it has the vitality of the we see it: the
compound in groups, like [illeg.] the great
caravans, painted, brought together into the
the [illeg.] comes together on the [finial?]
from the ground. Sometimes the comment is
perfectly free, expressive of some still of
some emotion; & then the [warbly]
becomes sound merely, the [illeg.] merely,
an incantation; & it passes
away like a cloud; sleep, indifference,
[illeg.], along the ear, – still
we must return to it, because of the
language – partly for that love of the
old they seem: it is the thing itself: not
or : it is & [pearly?]
a [illeg.] such a poem as an exile might
write by way of refuge from the
damp of & the savagery of the Irish
country

voluptuous, his love of sound, his addiction the sweetness of the

for him to destroy; or to abolish.

He stands then, at the threshold of the great hall,
– "a little man with short hair, a small hand &
cuffs'– looking back at ; & He
This public is a reading aloud public of nobles;
& he has, perhaps the disturbing [anticipation?]
of a language to whuch anything may happen.
His desire to fasten to to the old English of
Chaucer arose perhaps from his a
sense that we cannot sense long lost to us -–
a sense of the future. Suppose that he
Why look back to Chaucer, why graft his
what was going to happen to this new
[attendantly?] growing speech which he must
with his sensibility to words he must have
felt – everywhere – in talk, in songs –
it

And so we reach the force wh.
The future This is a sense that only comes
The sense of the future is almost extinct, now.
But then, the writer must have been
aware, with the agitation of
that something it was all to come.

to the shelves of college libraries were the Greek &
Roman classics. The learned read them; & the nobles.
"...our ancient ladies of the court" when they
did the were to be found reading the holy
scriptiores or they did their needlework; &
histories; , made no
show against these august ancients
There they sit, in the palace, embroidering, reading,
playing their musical instrument; &
the background of the mind is in Italy, in France, in
Greece; but in the foreground is England,
the background of the b eye is eye is

It – they are in
the background they are the ancestors to with whom the

now built of stone, no longer a hut made of branches,
no longer a ma of a cold smoky home
thick with smoke, no with a log for a pillow:
It is now It is now almost too luxurious
for an old clergyman; with pillows, &
silver, & glass windows; and the
Queen has a [barge?] & the London is a
city; & there, though (tho) he cannot see
himself
is , a [illeg.] yet
kindly man, using language,
which (wh.) would (wd) have shocked his ancestors,
adding a patron, , in
flowing [prose?] that would (wd) have shocked

The The age of anonymity is over.
